Expectation1: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation1: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Situation2: They set aside part of their routine to light a lamp and offer prayers at their home altar.
Story: The bell above the salon door chimed just as I was about to light the lamp at my home altar in the back room. My hands trembled, the match poised above the wick, when I heard the hesitant footsteps. I peeked out and saw a woman standing awkwardly by the reception desk, clutching her purse, eyes darting around the unfamiliar space. As a hairdresser, I knew I should greet her warmly, offer her tea, and help her feel at ease—first impressions mattered so much. But as a Hindu, this was my sacred moment, the time I set aside every day to offer prayers and light the lamp, a ritual that anchored me in peace. My heart pounded as I stood between the altar and the salon floor, torn between the gentle pull of my faith and the professional duty to welcome my client. I could feel the seconds stretching, the weight of both expectations pressing down on me, demanding I choose which part of myself to honor first.
